(b) The person subject to said occupation tax on the current calendar year shall, at the end of the preceding year, and on or before April 1 of the current calendar year, file with the city, on a form furnished by the city, a signed return setting forth the amount of gross receipts of such business for the entire preceding calendar year. This return will be used to determine the final tax for the calendar year just completed and as an estimate of the gross receipts and occupation tax for the current calendar year. (c) Where a business subject to the occupation tax for the calendar year has been conducted for only a part of the preceding year, the amount of gross receipts for such part shall be reported in said return. Said return shall also show a figure putting the receipts for such part of a year on an annual basis with the part-year receipts bearing the same ratio to the whole-year gross receipts as the part year bears to the whole year. Said figure shall be used as the estimate of the gross receipts of the business for the current calendar year in establishing the business tax liability. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 15A, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-99. - Filing of return showing actual gross receipts during calendar year; procedure where taxes overpaid or underpaid. (a) On or before April 1 of each year, the owner, proprietor, manager, or executive officer of the business liable for said occupation tax levied for the year shall file with the city, on a form furnished by the city, a signed return setting forth the actual amount of the gross receipts of such business during the preceding calendar year. (b) If the amount of the occupation tax for the preceding year, based on the return provided for in this section and on the rate of said tax provided for in this article, is less than the amount of occupation tax theretofore paid by said business based on the estimate filed by the business, the difference in said amount shall be due and payable by the taxpayer to the city on April 1 of the current year and is delinquent if not paid on or before said date. (c) If the amount of the occupation tax for the preceding year, based on the return provided for in this section and on the rate of said tax provided for in this article, exceeds the amount of occupation tax theretofore paid by said business based on the estimate filed by the business, the difference in said amount shall be refunded by the city to the taxpayer; or if said business continues to be conducted in the city during the current year, such difference in amount may be credited by the city of the amount of occupation tax to be paid to the city by said business for the current year. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 16, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-100. - Evidence of state registration; other qualifications. (a) Each person who is licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43 by the examining boards of the Secretary of State's Office shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before any city regulatory fee certificate may be issued. (b) Any person required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city registration, show evidence of such qualification. (c) Any person required to submit an annual application for continuance of that business shall do so before the registration is issued. (d) Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 18, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-101. - Liability of officers and agents, registration required, failure to obtain. All persons subject to the occupation tax required in this article shall be required to take out the necessary registration for said business prescribed in this article. In default thereof, the officer or agents soliciting for or obtaining business shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a certificate. Each person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration provided herein before commencing such business. Any person transacting or offering to transact any of the kinds of business without having first obtained such registration shall be subject to the penalties provided herein and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 18-102; provided, however, that obtaining the registration shall not be a prerequisite for commencement of practicing a profession or any other occupation whose qualification to practice or perform their profession or occupation is determined by the general laws of the state. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 19, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-102. - Due date, court penalty and interest. A penalty is imposed on each business and practitioner of an occupation which or who fails to apply for and obtain appropriate registration and to pay any and all regulatory and administrative fees and occupation taxes required by this article prior to April 1 of each year. Said penalty shall be in the amount of ten percent of the regulatory and administrative fee and occupational tax determined to be due and owing under the provisions of this article. Such delinquency shall also bear interest at the rate of 1½ percent each month or partial month of such delinquency. Penalties provided herein shall be in addition to any other penalties, civil or criminal, which may be applicable. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 20, 1-22-2015) State Law reference— Late payment penalty, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21. Sec. 18-103. - Inspection of records. The city, through its employees, officers, or agents, may inspect the books of any person or business subject to an occupation tax to determine the accuracy of the documents and information submitted by a business or practitioner to the city. Failure to submit such books or records within 30 days from the date of a written request by the city shall be grounds for revocation of the regulatory fee certificate and/or occupation tax certificate, and to the extent applicable, shall revoke the right of the person or business to do business within the city. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the designated city agents. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency exists as a result of improper designation of a dominant line of a business, profession or occupation, a penalty of ten percent of the deficiency and an additional interest of one percent per month of the amount of the deficiency shall be added. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 22, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-104. - Revocation. Failure of any person to pay an applicable administrative fee, regulatory fee or occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent or upon failure to permit inspection of books as required, shall result in any business tax certificate or regulatory fee certificate granted by the city under this article permitting such person to do business in the city for the current year being automatically revoked without any further action required of the city. No new occupation tax certificate or regulatory fee certificate shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax or fees herein required are unpaid, nor shall such certificates be issued to a person who has failed to submit adequate records for inspection as required by section 18-103. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 23, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-105. - Execution, liens. (a) The mayor, or his designee, upon any tax or installment of any tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue an execution for the amount of said tax against the person liable for said tax, including interest at the rate of one percent per month accruing thereon. The lien shall cover the property of the person liable for said tax as provided by this article, the Charter of the city and the laws of the state. The lien for said occupation tax shall become fixed on and dated from the time that such tax or installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the appropriate city agent upon the property of the person liable for said tax, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest and cost allowed by law. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be provided by this article and other applicable ordinances of the city, the Charter of the city and the laws of the state. The defendants at execution shall have the rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality of the tax or otherwise as provided by the Charter of the city and the laws of the state in regard to tax executions. (b) When a nulla bona entry has been entered by the proper authority upon execution issued by the city against any person or business defaulting on an occupation tax, or regulatory fee, the person or business against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered or goods provided after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of the nulla bona has been made, the person or business against whom the execution has been issued pays the tax in full, together with all interest, penalties and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges for services and goods due the person as though the person had never defaulted in the payment of taxes; provided, however, that nothing in this subsection shall be construed to restrict in any way the ability of those practicing a profession or any other occupation whose qualification to practice or perform their profession or occupation is determined by the general laws of the state to perform that profession or occupation and to collect fees or charges therefor. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 24, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-106. - Application to prior delinquencies. This article does not repeal or affect the enforcement of any ordinance or part of any ordinance heretofore passed for fees and taxes levied when such fees and taxes have not been paid in full. Such ordinances and parts of ordinances heretofore passed providing for the issuing and enforcing execution for taxes or assessments required by such ordinances or that imposed fines or penalties for nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees pursuant to such ordinances, or failure to comply with the other provisions thereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee or assessment shall be fully paid. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 25, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-107. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by governing body. This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the council. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 26, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-108. - Applicability of article. This article shall not apply to those businesses subject to separate ordinance of the city; those businesses or practitioners excluded under the terms of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-16 and 48-13-19(c); as well as those business or practitioners excluded or exempted under any other section of the Official Code of Georgia or by the constitution of the state, or by the laws or Constitution of the United States. (Ord. No. O-008-15, § 29, 1-22-2015) Sec. 18-109. - Tax rate schedule. CITY OF MCRAE TAX RATE SCHEDULE
(Ord. No. O-008-15, app. A, 1-22-2015) ARTICLE V. - AD VALOREM TAXATION
Sec. 18-110. - Manner, time of issuing execution. Executions for nonpayment of ad valorem taxes and other indebtedness due the city shall be issued by the city clerk, or its designee, when delinquent. (Ord. No. O-032-18, § 1, 6-14-2018) Sec. 18-111. - Receipt to be attached to execution; record. When executions for taxes have been issued, it shall be the duty of the clerk, or its designee, to attach the unsigned tax receipt of the taxpayer to the execution and place the execution in the hands of the one of the officers designated in section 18-110. The clerk shall keep an accurate record of the execution delivered to each officer, including the name of the officer and the date of delivery of the execution to him. (Ord. No. O-032-18, § 1, 6-14-2018) Sec. 18-112. - Interest on past-due taxes and assessments; penalty, and fifa cost. All taxes and assessments past due shall bear interest at the maximum rate allowed under state law. In addition, the maximum penalty allowed by state law and a fifa cost of $12.00 on any past due taxes and assessments shall be charged and collected. The clerk shall collect the interest, penalty, and fifa cost on past due items and make a separate record thereof. (Ord. No. O-032-18, § 1, 6-14-2018) Sec. 18-113. - City marshal designated; fee for tax levy; tax sale. The mayor and council may designate a city marshal or code enforcement officer whose name shall be entered in the minutes of the mayor and council and who may be removed by mayor and council with or without cause at any time. The mayor and council may also designate an additional city marshal, if, in their judgement, the need exists and such appointment may be made on a temporary basis. Once a levy is made or posted on the property of a delinquent or defaulting taxpayer, the marshal, code enforcement officer or an appointee shall collect, in addition to any other costs, interest, and penalties, the actual expenses incurred by the city in issuing the execution and administering the levy by imposing a levy administration fee which shall be five percent of the delinquent tax or $250.00 whichever is the lesser. Regardless of any other provision of this section, however, no such levy administration fee shall be less than $50.00. (Ord. No. O-032-18, § 1, 6-14-2018) Sec. 18-114. - Property tax; levied; rate. A tax on the taxable real and personal property located within the city is hereby levied and shall be collected for the purpose of operating the city, the maintaining of its government and for other lawful uses in connection with the furtherance of the city's welfare. The city's annual millage rate shall be as adopted by resolution of the mayor and council. (Ord. No. O-032-18, § 1, 6-14-2018) Sec. 18-115. - Due date for returns and payment of taxes. All ad valorem taxes shall be payable on or before December 20 of the year in which levied and assessed. (Ord. No. O-032-18, § 1, 6-14-2018) Sec. 18-116. - City authorized to collect expenses at tax sale. The city shall be authorized at tax sale as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359 to collect any and all expenses associated with the collection of ad valorem taxes on such real property, including any expenses incurred in the collection of such taxes. (Ord. No. O-032-18, § 1, 6-14-2018) Secs. 18-117—18-125. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - PEDDLERS AND OTHER TRANSIENT MERCHANTS
Sec. 18-126. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Charitable organization means any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary (of, relating to, or supported by charity or alms) corporation, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint-stock company, trust, unincorporated organization or individual who solicits or obtains contributions solicited from the general public for charitable purposes. Charitable purpose means any charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary purpose for religion, health, education, social welfare, arts and humanities, environment, civic, or public interest. Door-to-door salesperson means any person who goes from house to house, from place to place, or from street to street, soliciting or taking or attempting to take orders for any goods, wares, or merchandise, including books, periodicals, magazines or personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or seeking information, money, donations or financial assistance for any purpose whatsoever, or soliciting or taking or attempting to take orders for services to be furnished or performed in the future. Goods means merchandise, wares, fabric, material, furniture, clothing, shoes, or any other articles of commerce; provided, however, that "goods" shall not include the sale of motorized vehicles or boats. Peddler means any person who goes from house to house, from place to place, or from street to street, carrying or transporting goods, wares, or merchandise and offering or exposing the same for sale, or making sales and deliveries to purchasers, or giving or leaving leaflets, pamphlets or other items that promote or advertise the sale of goods or the provision of services for profit. Red light fundraiser means the solicitation of monetary donations or other donations of things of value made by a charitable organization or religious organization for charitable purposes at a traffic light intersection. For the purposes of a red light fundraiser, individuals shall not be included in the definition of charitable organization or religious organization. Religious organization means an entity which is qualified as a religious organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. Solicit and solicitation mean the request directly or indirectly of money, credit, property, financial assistance or other things of value from another. These requests may be accomplished by using any of the following methods: (1) Any oral or written request; or (2) The sale of, offer or attempt to sell, any advertisement, advertising space, book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine, membership, merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing. The term "solicitation" shall be deemed completed when made, whether or not the person making the same received any contribution or makes any sale referred to in this article. Transient merchant means any person, firm or corporation, as principal or agent, or both, which is not a regular retail or wholesale merchant with a permanent place of business in this state, but rather one who displays samples, goods, wares, or merchandise in any lot, building, structure, or vehicle for the purpose of securing orders for the sale of such item or items of like kind of quality for future or immediate delivery, or one who sells food, drink, produce, or like products from a temporary site or structure. The terms "door-to-door salesperson," "transient merchant" and "peddler" shall not include any person, firm or corporation who solicits orders for future delivery of goods to merchants for the merchant's resale. The orders solicited from merchants shall be orders for future delivery only. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018; Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018) Sec. 18-127. - Exclusions. This article shall not apply to: (1) Any person, firm, or corporation which solicits sales for charitable organizations, charitable purposes, or on behalf of religious organizations, political organizations, or political candidates. (2) Any person, firm, or corporation which conducts business at any industry or association trade show or at any craft show or festival of not more than three days in duration (3) Any person, firm, or corporation which sells items at a flea market, antique mall or similar place of business where such place has a business license. (4) Sales made to or by dealers, traders, manufacturers, merchants, or businesses at their established places of business within the incorporated limits of the city. (5) Annual sidewalk sale (otherwise known as "Peaches to Beaches") which is part of economic development promotional activities by the Telfair County Chamber of Commerce (6) Residential yard sales conducted in accordance to the provisions of [section] 18-145 of this Code. Such persons who qualify for any exemption outlined in this section shall remain subject to the prohibitions set forth in sections 18-128 through 18-146. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-128. - Registration required; duration of registration. Each peddler, transient merchant, and door-to-door sales person who does business within the city shall be required to obtain a registration from the city, in the manner specified in this article. Every such registration shall be valid for such continuous period as the merchant applies for as stated in section 18-131. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-129. - Requirements for corporations; registered agents. (a) It shall be unlawful for any peddler or transient merchant or door-to-door salesperson which is a corporation to engage in business within the city unless such corporation shall comply with all applicable provisions of O.C.G.A. § 14-2-101 et seq., relating to corporations and obtain a registration. (b) It shall be unlawful for any peddler or transient merchant or door-to-door salesperson which is not a corporation engage in business within the city unless such person shall have and maintain a registered agent(s) and shall obtain a permit. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-130. - Applications. (a) All peddlers and transient merchants and door-to-door salespersons shall file an application for a registration with the office of the city manager. Such application shall include, but not be limited to, the following: (1) The name, permanent address, and telephone number of the individual peddler or transient merchant or door-to-door salesperson, and if applicable the name and address of the corporate registered agent or office. (2) Type of business to be conducted and nature of goods to be sold. (3) The date and place of incorporation, when such peddler or transient merchant is a corporation (4) The address, location, or general area where business is to be conducted. (5) Written consent by property owner if the intended location is not the property of the applicant for the conduct of business thereon. (6) A copy of photographic identification. (7) If employed, the name and address of the employer. (8) The length of time for which the right to do business is desired. (9) If the goods are not available for receipt at time of purchase, the place where the goods or property to be sold are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery. (10) A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, offense, or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense, and the punishment or penalty assessed therefore. (11) Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand, accept, or receive payment or deposit money in advance of final delivery. (12) The last three municipalities wherein the applicant has worked before coming to this city. (13) Such other relevant information as may be required by the investigation of this applicant. (b) As part of the application process, each applicant and each representative for a corporation shall submit to a criminal background check by the police department. (c) Applications in which the location of a transient merchant will unduly impede traffic or compromise public safety will not be approved. (d) As part of the registration process, each transient merchant applicant designating any one or more stationary addresses or locations owned by another where business is to be conducted, shall submit with such application a written statement showing the consent of the property owner for the applicant to transact business thereon. (e) At the time of filing this application, the applicant shall present his driver's license, if in possession of one, to the city clerk or her representative. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-131. - Fee. Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant shall pay a non-refundable fee, based upon the duration in which he intends to do business in the city, as follows: Per day: $50.00 Per week: $200.00 Such fee schedule shall be adopted by resolution of the McRae-Helena Mayor and Council and may be amended from time to time by resolution. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-132. - Display. Every peddler, transient merchant, or door-to-door salesperson issued a permit under the provisions of this article and doing business within the city shall display his permit upon the request by any person and failure to do so shall be deemed an offense. If a stand, vehicle, or room is used in the conduct of business, the permit shall be displayed so as to be easily visible to the public. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-133. - Loud noise and amplification devices prohibited. No registration holder under the provisions of this article shall shout, ring bells, blow horns, make loud noises or use any radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks, or other public places within the city for the purpose of attracting attention to the goods, wares, or merchandise which such registrant intends to sell. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-134. - Additional regulations for transient merchants. (a) Transient merchants shall conduct business only in locations zoned commercial and in accordance with appendix A, zoning of the city Code. (b) All vehicles must be removed from the transient merchant's location at the end of each workday. (c) All vehicles associated with the business shall be parked on asphalt or concrete and outside of the right-of-way. (d) No transient merchant shall conduct business in between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-135. - Additional regulations for door-to-door salespersons. (a) The police department shall provide each registered door-to-door salesperson with an information card, and the door-to-door salesperson shall present this card to each household he visits. It is the responsibility of the salesperson to pick up this card and return it to the police department after expiration of the permit. (b) At any home or business where a "no soliciting" sign is posted, no soliciting shall be made. (c) No door-to-door salesperson shall enter a home except at the express invitation of the occupant. Any residential occupant may refuse entry, or to ask the door-to-door salesperson to leave the premises after allowing entry, and if the door-to-door salesperson should fail to leave the premises after such instructions, he shall be in violation of the laws of this state and ordinances of the city. (d) At each house where a door-to-door salesperson calls for sales, the door-to-door salesperson shall announce to the owner or occupant of the home his name and that he has been issued a permit by or has been registered with the City of McRae-Helena as a door-to-door salesperson and shall announce the purpose of his call and present the card provided by the police department. (e) A door-to-door salesperson shall at all times maintain a courteous decorum and shall not use opprobrious words to any homeowner or occupant. No door-to-door salesperson shall remain upon the premises of an occupant or owner after such occupant or owner has requested the door-to-door salesperson to leave or has indicated that he is not interested in purchasing the product. (f) It shall be unlawful for any door-to-door salesperson to represent by word, action, or deed that the issuance of a permit by the city in any way represents approval of either the action of the salesperson or his product or organization. (g) If a door-to-door salesperson shall secure an order from an owner or occupant, such salesperson shall inform the owner or occupant as to his rights under the home solicitation act of the state. This may be done by the door-to-door salesperson leaving a written card or document specifying the rights of a homeowner or occupant under the Retail Installment and Home Solicitation Sales Act (O.C.G.A. § 10-1-1 et seq.) (h) It shall be unlawful for any person to make any more than one solicitation call at the same premises for identical goods or services within any consecutive two-week period, without receiving prior invitation by the occupant of the premises. (i) It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or attempt to solicit at a place of residence at any entrance or part of the building other than the main entrance. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-136. - Denial of applications; revocation of registration. (a) Applications for registration for individual peddlers and transient merchants and door-to-door salesperson shall be denied for: (1) Any person who has been convicted within the past seven years of any felony offense of moral turpitude; (2) Any person who has been convicted within the past seven years of any misdemeanor involving any crime of moral turpitude or physical violence (3) Any person who has, within the past seven years, had revoked his business license or transient merchant's license by a local government. (b) Denial of registration may be appealed by the applicant to the mayor and council, by filing of a written appeal, including the legal and factual basis for appeal, with the city clerk not later than seven business days after dispatch of written notice of denial to applicant. On appeal, the mayor and council may correct any errors of law or fact, but may not grant a registration to any individual whose background is in violation of the requirements of this article. The mayor and council will convene within 45 days of receiving an appeal to render a decision. (c) Registrations may be revoked or otherwise sanctioned in the same manner and upon the same basis as for the revocation of business licenses and occupation tax registrations. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-137. - Refusing to leave. Any peddler, transient merchant, or door-to-door salesperson who enters upon premises owned, leased, or rented by another and refuses to leave such premises after having been notified by the owner or occupant of such premises, or his agent, to leave the same and not return to such premises, shall be deemed guilty of an offense. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-138. - Misrepresentation. It shall be unlawful for any peddler to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality of his goods, wares, merchandise or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the same. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-139. - Hours of operation. It shall be unlawful for any transient merchant or door-to-door salesperson to operate business within the city between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. the following morning. Additionally, door-to-door salespersons and peddlers shall not operate business at any time on Sundays, except by specific appointment with or invitation from the prospective customer. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-140. - False information. It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false or misleading information in connection with his application for a permit required by this article. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-141. - Investigation. Upon receipt of an application for a permit required by this article, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. The chief of police shall complete his investigation within one week of receiving the application. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-142. - Issuance. If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval and return the application to the city clerk, who shall deliver the permit to the applicant. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-143. - Contents of permit. Each permit issued under this article shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name and address of the permittee, the class of the permit issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance, and the length of time and same shall be operative, as well as the permit number. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-144. - Duration. Every permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for the period of time stated therein, but in no event shall any such permit be issued for a period of time in excess of one month. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-145. - Residential yard sales. Residents of the City of McRae-Helena may have up to four yard sales per year. A permit fee of $3.00 per day and an application shall be submitted to city hall. Yard sale duration shall not exceed two consecutive days. Yard sales authorized by this provision shall be limited to residential property in McRae-Helena and shall not occur in commercial districts. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-146. - Enforcement and penalty for violation. (a) The city manager or her designee shall be the enforcement officer for the provisions of this article and shall insure that the provisions are complied with prior to the issuing of any license. (b) Any person, firm, partnership, or corporation that violates the terms of this division shall upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. (Ord. No. O-034-18, 7-12-2018) Sec. 18-147. - Solicitation banned within fifteen feet of the right-of-way of city intersections. It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or organization of any type to solicit within 15 feet of the right-of-way of any road intersection in the city unless otherwise allowed by this article. (Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018) Sec. 18-148. - Red light fundraisers allowed in certain locations at certain times. (a) Notwithstanding the foregoing section, red light fundraisers, as defined in this article, shall be permitted at the intersections of Third Avenue and Oak Street and Third Avenue and Martin Luther King, Jr. Boulevard at certain times and upon certain conditions as provided by this article. (b) Red light fundraisers shall only be held on Saturdays and will begin no earlier than 9:00 a.m. and will end no later than 12:00 p.m. (Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018) Sec. 18-149. - Conduct of solicitation at red light fundraiser. (a) It shall be unlawful with respect to any person, organization, or entity participating in a red light fundraiser on or within 15 feet of any public right-of-way, to conduct its business in such a manner that the flow of vehicular traffic is impeded. Solicitations from travel lanes shall not be permitted; provided however, that walking alongside a line of cars may be permitted if the person stays out of the travel lanes and the solicitation occurs when the traffic light is red and cars are stopped. No sales or gifts to vehicle occupants shall be permitted. (b) No person under the age of 15 shall be allowed to set foot on the roadway at any red light fundraiser. (c) For every six people participating at a red light fundraiser who are age 18 or under, there shall be at least one person designated to the city as a supervisor of them. Such supervisors shall be 19 years of age or older. (d) Every person participating at a red light fundraiser shall at all times wear an orange or green safety vest satisfactory to the McRae-Helena Police Department. In no event shall a brightly colored shirt be allowed to substitute for a safety vest. (e) The city shall not be liable for any accidents, injuries, or damages incurred relating to any red light fundraisers. (Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018) Sec. 18-150. - Application for red light fundraiser permit. (a) Each organization desiring to conduct a red light fundraiser shall file an application for a permit to do so with the office of the city manager. Such application shall include, but not be limited to, the following: (1) The name, permanent address, and telephone number of the corporate registered agent or office of the organization or other such person authorized to legally contract on behalf of the organization. (2) The intersection at which the fundraiser is to be conducted. (3) A copy of photographic identification. (4) The date and length of time for which the fundraiser is to be conducted. (5) The designation of any supervisors for those participants whom supervision is required for by this article. (6) The execution of a hold harmless and release agreement with the city. (b) Organizations shall make an application to the city for a permit to conduct a red light fundraiser no later than two weeks prior to the requested date of the fundraiser. (c) Only one application for a red light fundraiser shall be approved for any organization during the calendar year. (d) Any application for a requested fundraiser date shall be received by the city at least two weeks in advance of the requested date. (e) There shall be no more than one organization holding a red light fundraiser at any intersection at a given time. Application approvals shall be made on a first come, first served basis. (f) All applicants for a permit to conduct a red light fundraiser shall provide proof of general liability insurance including products liability and property damage in the amount of $1,000,000.00 combined single limit. A certificate of insurance and a blanket or specific endorsement shall be delivered to the city clerk prior to the issuance of a permit and shall name as additional insureds the city and its employees regarding any liabilities that may arise in connection with the operations of the applicant. (Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018) Sec. 18-151. - Red light fundraiser permit fee. There shall initially be no fee for the permit required to conduct a red light fundraiser. However, the city reserves the right to require an applicant to pay a non-refundable fee for obtaining such permit, which shall be set by the city from time to time. (Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018) Sec. 18-152. - Issuance and contents of red light fundraiser permit. Upon the approval of any application for a permit to conduct a red light fundraiser, the city shall cause to be issued a written permit therefore. Such permit shall contain the signature of the city clerk or city manager and shall show the name and address of the permittee, the date of issuance, the approved date for the fundraiser, the duration of the fundraiser, and a permit number. (Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018) Sec. 18-153. - Applicability of other ordinances to red light fundraisers. All other ordinances within the McRae-Helena City Code not specifically addressed by this article shall remain applicable to organizations conducting red light fundraisers. (Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018) Sec. 18-154. - Violations of red light fundraiser ordinance and penalties. Any organization conducting a red light fundraiser that violates any provision of this article or any other provision of the McRae-Helena City Code or who makes any misrepresentation to the city in conjunction with its application for or conduct of a red light fundraiser shall be subject to the immediate revocation of its permit. Any such violations may also serve as grounds for the denial of future applications for a duration to be determined by the McRae-Helena Police Chief according to the severity of the violation or misrepresentation. Any objection to the validity of such denial may be appealed directly to the city council. (Ord. No. O-036-18, 9-13-2018)

div.head: Chapter 20 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.
Sec. 20-1. - Municipal judge. The municipal judge shall preside over the city's municipal court on the second Tuesday of every month at 3:00 p.m. The compensation for the judge shall be $500.00 per month. (Ord. No. O-001-15, § 6, 1-1-2015) Sec. 20-2. - Prosecuting attorney. (a) Short title. This section shall be known as the "Prosecuting Attorney of the McRae-Helena Municipal Court Ordinance." (b) Findings and intent. This section is adopted to address requirements made under state law for the city to pass an ordinance or resolution creating the office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court should the city choose to hire or have a prosecuting attorney of the municipal court. Under state law, in order to have a municipal court prosecutor, the city must pass this ordinance or resolution and provide to the prosecuting attorneys' council of the state a copy of the same. The city is also required to submit the name of the person appointed to be the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court within 30 days of such appointment in order to maintain the office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court. It is therefore the intent of the city to comply with state law, particularly O.C.G.A. title 15, ch. 18, art. 5 (O.C.G.A. § 15-18-90 et seq.), and to enact this article. (c) Establishment of office. The office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court is hereby established for the purpose of providing representation of the city in all of those matters enumerated in O.C.G.A. § 15-18-96 and as may be otherwise allowed by state law. The prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall be a part-time position. (d) Qualifications. The prosecuting attorney for the municipal court of the city shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia and admitted to practice before the trial and appellate courts of the state. Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from appointing the city attorney to be the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court, so long as all other requirements under the law are met. (e) Oath. The prosecuting attorney of the municipal court for the city shall take and subscribe to the following oath: "I swear (or affirm) that I will well, faithfully, and impartially and without fear, favor, or affection discharge my duties as prosecuting attorney of the Municipal Court for the City of McRae-Helena. I do further swear (or affirm) that I am not the holder of any unaccounted for public money due this State, or any political subdivision or authority thereof; that I am not the holder of any office of trust under the government of the United States, any other state, or any foreign state which I am prohibited from holding by the laws of the State of Georgia; and that I am otherwise qualified to hold said office, according to the Constitution and Laws of Georgia; and that I will support the Constitution of the United States and of this state. So help me God." (f) Term of office. The prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall serve until otherwise designated by the mayor and council as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 15-18-91(c). It shall be at the discretion of the city council to appoint a prosecutor upon the vacancy of position. (g) Jurisdiction, duties, and authority. The office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court for the city shall have the duty and authority to represent the city as defined by the city Charter and by state law, particularly as described in O.C.G.A. § 15-18-96. The prosecuting attorney may engage in the private practice of law, but shall not practice in the municipal court or appear in any matter in which the prosecuting attorney has exercised jurisdiction. (h) Disqualification or incapacity of prosecuting attorney; substitution. If the prosecuting attorney is disqualified from engaging in the prosecution of a particular case or is unable to perform the duties of said office due to illness or incapacity, the city shall provide for the appointment of a substitute prosecuting attorney. At any time in which a substitute prosecuting attorney is not available or an appointment has not been made, the city attorney may serve as the substitute prosecuting attorney until such time as a prosecuting attorney or substitute prosecuting attorney is available or appointed. (Ord. No. O-019-16, § 1(I)—(VIII), 3-10-2016)

div.head: Chapter 22 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
Chapter 24 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Local government recreational systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 24-1—24-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC CONDUCT IN PARKS
Sec. 24-19. - Hours. Parks and recreation facilities shall open at sunrise and shall close at sunset. Applicable closing signs shall be conspicuously posted at all parks and recreation facilities, and any deviation from these times must be approved in writing by the city. (Ord. No. O-025-17, § 1, 7-13-2017) Sec. 24-20. - Motor vehicles in parks. (a) A motorized vehicle means a self-propelled, wheeled conveyance that does not run on rails. A motorized vehicle shall not include a wheelchair used by a person with disabilities as an auxiliary aid. A wheelchair means a device designed solely for use by a mobility-impaired person for locomotion that is suitable for use in an indoor pedestrian area. (b) No person shall operate a motorized vehicle of any kind or nature, including, but limited to, all-terrain vehicles, utility task vehicles, and motorcycles, in or on any city park, bicycle path, or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. This section does not prohibit persons with disabilities from using a wheelchair as an auxiliary aid in or on any city park, bicycle path, or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. (c) This section does not prohibit the use of motorized vehicles for maintenance purposes by city personnel or motorized vehicles using marked roads, driveways or parking areas. Such motorized vehicles must remain on marked roads or in designated parking areas and drive at a speed not exceeding five miles per hour when in a city park. (Ord. No. O-025-17, § 2, 7-13-2017) Sec. 24-21. - Prohibitions. (a) Alcoholic beverages. No person shall serve, consume, or transport in open containers any alcoholic beverage within a city park or recreation facility. (b) Glass containers. No person shall possess a glass container in or on any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreation purposes. (c) Bicycles on athletic fields. No person shall ride or walk a bicycle or other non-motorized vehicle in or on any athletic field owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. This section does not prohibit persons with disabilities from using a wheelchair as defined in section 24-20 as an auxiliary aid on such fields. (d) Fires. It shall be unlawful for any person to build or maintain a fire in any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. (e) Fireworks. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or set off any fireworks or other explosive devices. (f) Littering. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, dump, or deposit litter on the grounds, streets, sidewalks, ponds, lakes, or other body of water in any city park or recreation facility. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the recreation facility by the person responsible for its presence and shall be properly disposed of elsewhere. (g) Commercial activity. It shall be unlawful for any person in any city park to: (1) Sell or offer for sale any merchandise; (2) Operate or attempt to operate a concession; or (3) Engage in any commercial or charitable activity in a city park. (h) Bicycles on park trails and paths. (1) No person shall ride, carry, push or otherwise manually transport a one-, two- or three-wheeled cycle on or through any trails owned or operated by the city and designed solely for pedestrian use. (2) This subsection (h) does not prohibit the use of such cycles on trails or paths specifically designated for bicycling or multi-uses that include cycling. (3) This subsection (h) does not prohibit persons with disabilities from using a wheelchair, as defined in section 24-20 as an auxiliary aid, on city-owned or city-operated trails and paths. (Ord. No. O-025-17, § 3, 7-13-2017) Sec. 24-22. - Swimming. (a) Swimming is prohibited in lakes, ponds, or creeks located inside any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. (b) Entering and using any body of water located in any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes for bathing or excretory functions is unlawful. (Ord. No. O-025-17, § 4, 7-13-2017) Sec. 24-23. - Watercraft. (a) Lakes and streams located in city parks or other areas owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes may be used for non-motorized boating. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a watercraft with a petroleum-based, fuel-burning engine in any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. (b) All watercraft must be carried by hand to the water's edge for launching. Watercraft shall not be permitted to be towed by vehicle to the edge of any body of water in any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. (c) This section shall not apply to official use of watercraft by law enforcement, fire and rescue personnel, or by city crews for maintenance and inspection. (Ord. No. O-025-17, § 5, 7-13-2017) Sec. 24-24. - Removal of vegetation, city property. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to dig up, cut, damage or remove any tree, tree limb, shrubbery, flower, rock, mulch or other vegetation/natural fixture located in any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. (b) This section shall not apply to personnel employed or engaged by the city to maintain city parks and recreational areas or an authorized group of volunteers involved in a city-approved project for the enhancement of a park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. (Ord. No. O-025-17, § 6, 7-13-2017) Sec. 24-25. - Native wildlife. (a) It shall be unlawful to remove or disturb any living or dead native creatures in city parks, including mammals, birds, amphibians, and reptiles, or the parts or progeny thereof, such as nests, eggs, or antlers. (b) Fishing activities in city park lakes or streams shall be allowed from the shore of a body of water or from non-motorized watercraft, if the location is designated by a city sign as allowing fishing at that particular location. (Ord. No. O-025-17, § 7, 7-13-2017) Sec. 24-26. - Enforcement. (a) The city police department, in connection with their duties imposed by law, shall diligently enforce the provisions of this article. (b) The city police department shall have the authority to order any person acting in violation of this article to leave the park or recreation area. (Ord. No. O-025-17, § 8, 7-13-2017)

div.head: Chapter 26 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; hazardous waste disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-61 et seq.; littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-42 et seq.
Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Ashes means and includes the waste product from coal, wood, or other fuels used for cooking and heating. Brown goods includes such items as chairs, mattresses, sofas, tables, and other furniture items. Building refuse means solid waste generated from construction or demolition activities undertaken on property located within the corporate limits of the city. The term "building refuse" includes, but is not limited to, lumber, brick, block, stone, carpet, plumbing materials, plaster, concrete, roofing, floor tile, gutters, and other substances accumulated as a result of construction of or repairs or additions to structures or accessory structures or the demolition thereof. Bulk waste means appliances, furniture, bedding material, automobile parts, mechanical equipment, mechanical parts, and carpet. Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. Department means the public works department or its successor. Director means the director of the public works department of his designee. Discard means to throw, abandon, place, deposit, discharge, dump, bury, burn or dispose of a substance. Disposable trash containers means plastic bags and cardboard, wooden and corrugated boxes which shall be nonreturnable and shall be collected and packed into the garbage truck collecting such items. Disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of solid waste occurs and includes, but is not limited to, landfilling and solid waste thermal treatment technology facilities. Dump means to throw, discard, place, deposit, discharge, bury, burn or dispose of a substance. Front-loading container means a heavy-duty steel container designed for use in commercial, industrial, and apartment units for storage of garbage, miscellaneous rubbish, trash and other waste. Garbage means all vegetable and animal matter, but not dead animals, food and other refuse from a kitchen, market, store, or elsewhere, including all matter that decays, attracts flies, and creates disagreeable odors. Hazardous waste means solid or liquid waste material resulting from the manufacture or use of chemicals, pesticides and drugs, other than normal household use, pathological waste, highly flammable, explosive waste, toxic waste, sewer sludge, insecticides, poisons, corrosives, caustics, acids, infectious materials, compressed gases, biological materials, radioactive materials, petroleum products and other waste material that is determined to be a hazard to public health, safety or environment. Industrial waste means solid waste generated by factories, processing plants, wholesale establishments, assembling plants, food processing wastes, cinders and ashes, lumber scraps, sawdust, shavings, including solids, semisolids, sludges, and liquids, floor sweepings, metal scrap and shavings, and any other waste products from industrial and manufacturing processes. Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate, which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. Litter means all discarded manmade materials, including, but not limited to, garbage, lottery tickets, household trash, industrial waste, building materials, appliances, or portions thereof, refuse, waste materials, sand, gravel, slag, brick bats, rubbish, tin cans, cigarette and cigar butts, other tobacco products, rags, cloths, newspapers, aluminum cans, trash, debris, dead animals, or any other discarded, used or unconsumed substance which is not handled in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Multiple residential unit means any duplex, dwelling place or apartment, or group of apartments under a single roof, or in a single apartment complex, used for a dwelling place for more than a one-family unit and which is served by a single water meter. Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks, and includes solid waste for single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term "municipal solid waste" includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste, but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvacultural operations or industrial processes or operations. Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including, but not limited to, municipal solid waste landfills. Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludges or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. Owner means any person, firm, or corporation owning, leasing, renting, occupying or managing any premises. Plastic bag means a polyethylene or other heavy-duty plastic bag meeting the National Sanitation Foundation Standard of 1.1 mills and not exceeding a 30-gallon capacity, with a securing twist tie. An untied plastic bag shall not be an approved container. Retail tire dealer means a person actively engaged in the business of selling new and used replacement tires. Rubbish means a variety of nonrecyclable household waste derived from places of residence and shall include paper, rags, plastics, cartons, boxes, broken glass bottles and jars, crockery, rubber, discarded clothing, and similar materials. Scrap tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage or defect. Scrap tire carrier means any person engaged in picking up or transporting scrap tires not otherwise exempted in the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management for the purpose of removal to a scrap tire processor, end user or disposal facility. Scrap tire generator means any person who generates scrap tires. The term "scrap tire generator" may include, but is not limited to, retail tire dealers, retreaders, scrap tire processors, automobile dealers, private company vehicle maintenance shops, garages, service stations, and city, county and state governments. Scrap tire processor means any person who is approved by the environmental protection division to receive scrap tires from scrap tire generators or scrap tire carriers for the purpose of scrap tire processing. Scrap tire sorter means any person, other than the original scrap tire generator, who handles mixed tires by separating used tires and retreadable casings from scrap tires. Single residential unit means any dwelling place occupied by one family unit and which is served by a single water meter. Solid waste means any garbage or refuse; sludge from wastewater treatment plants; solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from operations; mineral matter; metal and wooden furniture; appliances; large metal scraps and wires; wooden crates, boxes or pallets; dead animals; and other waste in a solid or semisolid state not otherwise defined in this section. Waste means discarded material, including, but not limited to, ashes, building refuse, garbage, hazardous waste, industrial refuse, recyclable waste, rubbish, solid waste, yard debris, tires, sand, gravel, slag, brick bats, trash, debris, dead animals, bottles, cans, boxes, containers, papers, tobacco products, appliances, mechanical equipment or parts, building or construction materials, tools, machinery, wood, motor vehicles or parts, vessels, aircraft equipment, waste oil, batteries, antifreeze, sludge from wastewater treatment plants or air pollution control facilities, and any other discarded material or substance of every kind and description resulting from domestic, industrial, commercial, governmental, or other operations. Wheeled container means a covered plastic or rubber container on wheels designed primarily for use by residential units for storage of garbage, miscellaneous refuse, trash and other waste. White goods means appliances such as stoves, refrigerators and other bulky household items primarily constructed of metal, parts of appliances, metal parts and miscellaneous metal. Yard debris means tree limbs, branches, stumps and logs, twigs, grass and shrub trimmings and clippings, bushes, weeds, leaves, and general yard and garden waste materials, and includes stone and dirt rakings and similar waste materials resulting from landscaping activities. Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvacultural operations. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 1, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-2. - Administration and enforcement. (a) The city manager or his designee shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. He may call upon the police department or code enforcement officer for assistance in its enforcement. (b) Upon determining that a violation of this chapter exists, the city manager or his designee shall cause written notice of such violation to be issued to the owner or occupier of the subject premises, setting forth the violation of the chapter and granting such owner or resident a reasonable time, not to exceed ten days, for the owner to correct said condition. (c) Upon determining that the owner has failed or refused to correct the condition within the time prescribed in the notice, the city manager or his designee shall cause a notice to be issued directing the owner or occupier of said premises to appear in the municipal court to answer the charge of violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 2, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-3. - Waste collection responsibility by the city. (a) The city shall be responsible for the collection and disposal of all garbage, solid waste, yard debris and rubbish within the city, and no person, unless otherwise authorized by a contract with the city, shall collect and dispose of or transport over the streets of the city any of such waste without first obtaining a written permit from the city to do so. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the city shall be authorized to enter into a contract with a private corporation or a public authority to provide for the collection and disposal of all garbage, solid waste, yard debris, and rubbish within the city. Such contract shall contain such terms and conditions as authorized by the city council and shall be for such length of time as may be determined by the city council and its citizens, but in no event shall such contract extend a length of time not otherwise authorized by the constitution and laws of the state. (b) The city shall not be responsible for the collection of hazardous waste and industrial refuse except as otherwise provided herein. The city shall not be responsible for the collection of building refuse. Such material must be disposed of by the builder, property owner, or tenant. In the case of new buildings, no certificate of occupancy shall be issued until the aforesaid material is removed by the owner or contractor. The disposal of all waste that is not subject to collection by the city shall be the responsibility of the person generating such waste. Such waste shall be disposed of in accordance with local, state and federal statutes, ordinances and regulations. (c) No person who owns or occupies any premises in the city shall permit trash, garbage, or other waste or rubbish to collect or remain on such premises, except during such periods between waste pickup; and no person who owns or occupies any premises in the city shall permit garbage, trash or other waste to be scattered from such premises into the public streets of the city. (d) Any owner of property who permits garbage, solid waste, building refuse, yard debris, recyclable waste and rubbish, hazardous waste or industrial refuse to become in a condition which is hazardous or dangerous to the public health, safety and welfare shall be notified in writing by the city manager or his designee to abate such condition within ten days of the date of such notice. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 3, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-4. - Refuse collection by city. (a) The city, or any entity with which the city has contracted for such purposes, shall make collections of waste from residential premises which have wheeled containers at least once weekly. The particular days of each week during which such collection shall occur shall be determined by the city manager or his designee or agent. (b) The city, or any entity with which the city has contracted for such purposes, shall make collections of waste from commercial and industrial premises which have wheeled containers at least weekly. The particular days of each week during which such collection shall occur shall be determined by the city manager or his designee or agent. (c) Yard debris and yard rubbish shall be collected by the city, or by any entity with which the city has contracted for such purposes, at least once a week on a schedule at such times as may be determined by the city manager or his designee or agent of the city. Such waste shall only be collected by the city when placed curbside. Wheeled containers shall not be utilized for disposal of such waste. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 4, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-5. - Garbage containers. (a) It shall be the duty of any owner or occupant of any single or multiple residential or commercial unit to place the wheeled container provided for such purpose on the assigned collection day at a front curbside location in such a manner as not to obstruct pedestrian passage, except that the city manager or his designee or agent may require the wheeled container to be placed on any side of a parcel of property for the reasons of topography or efficiency. (b) It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of a single or multiple residential or commercial unit to place the wheeled container at an appropriate curbside location at or before 7:00 a.m. or prior to the arrival of the sanitation truck. (c) It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any single or multiple residential or commercial unit to remove the wheeled container from the curbside location to a storage location, which storage location shall be nearer to the unit located on the premises than to any street abutting such premises; provided, however, that said removal shall be accomplished not later than 7:00 p.m. on the day the contents thereof are collected. (d) Garbage containers must be placed at least three feet away from vehicles, poles, fire hydrants, fences, overhead wires, low-hanging trees, branches, limbs, or other types of cover. (e) It shall be unlawful for any person to set fire to the contents of, indiscriminately scatter or disperse the contents of, or otherwise vandalize any container provided by the municipality or its agent for the dumping of garbage. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 5, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-6. - Pre-collection practices; prohibitions. (a) Front-loading containers. The city manager or his designee or agent shall determine the type, size, specifications, number and location of the garbage containers and shall determine the condition. (b) Secure containers. All containers shall be maintained at all times with tight-fitting lids or covers, and secured in such a manner as to prevent the overturning by the elements or by dogs or other animals. (c) Garbage and rubbish. Garbage and rubbish placed in containers for collection shall be enclosed in disposable watertight plastic bags with the top secured and placed in the container. (d) Injurious garbage or rubbish items. Garbage or rubbish placed for pickup with the potential for injury, such as broken glass, lightbulbs, sharp pieces of metal, fluorescent tubes, etc., shall be securely packaged or wrapped in such a manner to prevent injury to collection crews or other persons. (e) Pet litter. Pet litter must be placed in securely tied plastic bags and placed in the container. (f) Clean container. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or lessee of the property to keep the container clean. (g) Burying or burning litter or waste; written consent. No owner or occupant of any such property within the corporate limits shall bury or burn litter or waste without prior authorization and written consent from the applicable regulatory agency, including, but not limited to, the United States Environmental Protection Division and/or the state forestry commission. Nothing in this provision shall authorize or be construed to permit the burial or burning of any material which is otherwise prohibited by state and/or federal law. (h) Accumulation. No owner or occupant of any property shall cause, suffer, or allow the accumulation on his premises of garbage, litter or waste where such material creates or causes a health hazard to neighbors or other citizens, or which is unsightly or emits foul or obnoxious odors. (i) Stormwater collection system. It shall be unlawful for any person to dump any solid waste on any property, in any waters or in any stormwater collection system, except as authorized by applicable permits. It shall be the burden of the alleged violator to show proof of any applicable permits. (j) Storm drains. No person shall place any litter, refuse, trash, trees, grass, or other rubbish over or within five feet of a storm drain, drop inlet, culvert, or manhole. (k) Dumping. It shall be unlawful to dump, open dump, or permit the dumping of litter, waste, scrap tires, municipal, commercial, or industrial solid waste or recyclables at any place within the corporate city limits, including, and without limitations, in or on any public highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way, any public or private property in the city or any waters in the city, unless such litter or waste originates within the corporate limits of the city and the property is designated by the city council or its duly designated agent for the disposal of the above, and the material is placed into a receptacle or container designed for such property, and the property has a valid solid waste handling permit issued by the state environmental protection division (EPD) when required. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 6, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-7. - Garbage collection for disabled persons. Any person who is a full-time resident of a residential unit and who is disabled to the extent that such person is incapable of moving the wheeled container shall not be required to place the wheeled container at curbside as required in section 26-5. This section shall not apply unless all of the persons residing in a residential unit are also disabled. Provision for the collection of garbage from disabled residents shall be included in any contract approved by the city council for waste collection. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 7, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-8. - Sorting, storing, composting, and collecting yard debris. (a) All yard debris shall be subject to the following provisions: (1) Yard debris shall not be placed in or mixed with municipal solid waste. (2) Yard debris shall not be disposed of at municipal solid waste disposal facilities having liners and a leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the city (or at any such facility with which the city contracts). (3) Yard debris shall be sorted and stored for collection in such a manner as to facilitate collection, composting, or other handling. (b) The solid waste division of the public works department shall provide this service throughout the city. (c) The solid waste division shall not collect more than one load at any one location per predetermined route unless collected as an unscheduled service. A "load" is defined as six cubic yards. (d) Yard debris shall be placed between the curb and sidewalk where feasible. Where there is no sidewalk, limbs may be placed on the owner's property near the street. Limbs should be trimmed to six feet long and be no more than five inches in diameter. Limbs shall be stacked no closer than 50 feet to an intersection and placed in such a manner to not obstruct the view of traffic. Dirt, rocks, and roots shall not be collected by the city. (e) Leaves, limbs, grass, or other yard debris shall be placed in an orderly manner so as not to obstruct the free and normal flow of any drainage system or the safe vision or movement of any pedestrian or vehicular traffic. (f) Limbs cut and placed near the street for collection by any person other than the owner or legal occupant of the property shall not be collected or disposed of by the city. Individuals or companies under contract as privately employed tree trimmers, tree surgeons, landscape contractors, and operators of tree and shrubbery leaves and limbs maintenance shall haul and dispose of all such debris if said debris exceeds the definition of a load of yard debris. This requirement also applies to utility or railroad companies which trim vegetation away from their wires, equipment or tracks to maintain their right-of-way over public and private land. It shall be the duty of the occupant or owner of any premises to separate yard debris from all other municipal solid waste. (g) The on-site composting of yard trimmings is encouraged. Further, the development of low-maintenance landscaping is encouraged for commercial and industrial developments. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 8, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-9. - Brown and white goods collection. (a) Brown and white goods, as defined in section 26-1, must be separated from other waste. Brown and white goods shall be placed away from automobiles, mailboxes, fences, low-hanging limbs and wires or other items which might hamper collection. (b) The city will not pick up bulk brown and white goods from commercial establishments. (c) No more than two pieces of brown and white goods shall be placed out for pickup at the same time. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 9, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-10. - Unscheduled service. (a) The minimum charge for an unscheduled service for yard debris collection exceeding a load as defined in section 26-8(c) shall be $150.00 per load. (b) There shall be no unscheduled services for other solid waste collection. If collection for roll-out cart service was missed and the cart was placed at the curb by the time prescribed in section 26-5, the missed collection should be reported to city hall. (c) Payment must be received prior to collection. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 10, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-11. - Move outs and eviction. (a) For rental properties, garbage, trash, or other solid waste originating from the property during the cleanup between tenants or the eviction of tenants shall be the responsibility of the landlord and/or the property owner. Following an eviction, any property, trash, belongings, or other items shall be placed on some portion of the landlord's property, immediately behind the sidewalk or, if there is no sidewalk, a minimum of five feet behind the curb or off the pavement, and shall not be located as to impede or obstruct or divert either pedestrian or vehicular traffic or the flow of surface water or block drains. (b) Any property, trash, belongings, or other items placed curbside following an eviction shall be removed within 48 hours of the physical eviction by the property owner. (c) If not removed within 48 hours after notification by the city, that will constitute a violation of this Code and be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-8. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 11, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-12. - Collection routes and districts established. The areas of the city shall be divided into districts and collection routes by the public works director, and a map shall be available at city hall and any other area deemed appropriate for public viewing. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 12, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-13. - Service charges. The monthly bill for utilities sent to each utilities consumer for water and sewer service shall include charges for solid waste removal service and trash, leaf and limb collection at such rates therefor as are prescribed by resolution of the city council. The total amount of each monthly bill for the utility services shall be promptly paid by the consumer in full in accordance with the water connection policy. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 13, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-14. - Discontinuance of services to premises when charges remain unpaid. Any person failing for any reason or refusing to pay monthly the charge provided for in section 26-13 shall be subject to the discontinuance of city services in accordance with the same provisions of the water connection policy. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 14, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-15. - State of emergency. If a state of emergency has been declared by a person authorized to make such declaration or a natural disaster or occurrence has significantly impacted the area, residential yard debris collection shall be made in accordance with the emergency plans of the city, or as authorized by the city manager or his designee. (Ord. No. O-024-17, § 15, 5-11-2017) Sec. 26-16. - Scrap tires. (a) The owner or occupant of any premises shall be responsible for the sanitary handling and disposal of all scrap tires on the premises used or occupied by such person. (b) It shall be unlawful to cause, suffer or allow the dumping of scrap tires at any place, including, and without limitations, in or on any public highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way thereof, any public or private property or any waters, unless the property is designated by the city council and the state environmental protection division for the collection or disposal of scrap tires and the person is authorized to use such property. The scrap tires must be placed into a receptacle or container installed specifically for such property and the property shall have a valid solid waste handling permit or other applicable identification numbers, and approvals and/or permits issued by the state environmental protection division (EPD) when required. (c) All persons defined as scrap tire generators, scrap tire carriers, scrap tire processors, including scrap tire sorters, and retail tire dealers shall be subject to rules as defined in chapter 391-3-4 et seq., of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management, as amended, and handle scrap tires in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq., and the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management, chapter 391-3-4 et seq., as amended, applicable to solid waste, except where provisions of this section are more stringent, in which case the provisions of this section shall be applicable unless preempted by state law. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person in a residential zone to accumulate any amount of scrap tires on or around property, which they own or occupy. (e) A retail tire dealer may hold up to 100 scrap tires per garage bay in storage, up to a maximum of 1,000 scrap tires. (f) Tires must be stored in covered or enclosed areas to prevent the accumulation of water. (g) Any person, firm, or corporation violating any portion of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (1) The court may order the publication of the names and photographs of persons convicted of violating this section; (2) The court may order the person convicted hereunder to repair or restore property damaged, or pay damages resulting from such violations, or perform public service related to the repair or restoration of property damaged by the violation; (3) In case of a tire dump, the property owner, contractor, developer, builder or other person responsible for the property shall, upon conviction, cause the property to be cleaned and to come into full compliance with this section.
